title: 碎片
body:
20200902
微博v 何太极说，本金小的情况下，分散持仓不如重仓一个，有利于做大本金，并说，50w rmb以下就是小本金这么看来，我真的不用玩币了。
最近牛市初期，各种暴富消息又频频传来。可是我还在耗心耗力的奋斗中——亏损。
也是没谁了
记得上一轮17年的时候也是这样，但当时我刚进币圈，懵懵懂懂，只是看热闹，并由谨小慎微到头脑发热到做接盘侠…
本来以为到这一轮牛市我会好一些，可是最近两天我耗在yfii上的荒谬行径又让我依稀看到了2017-2018时的那个自己。
说到底，财不进急门。
那些稳定赚到不少钱的，是数学好、心态稳的人。
这些素质，一半是先天（遗传），一半是后天（锻炼身体、打坐…）。
没关系，赚适合自己的钱。
就算赚到了贝塔也是很好的呀。
关键是探索适合自己的和不适合自己的投资或者说生活方式。
我还是坚信，属于我的赚钱方式应该是不费力的、快乐的、滋养我的。

2020-09-02 

yfii复盘。

鉴于我在这个币上耗了很多的盯盘时间和紧张的精力，就复盘一下吧，提醒自己以后引以为戒。 

在cy的群里看到他推荐大家买yfii时，我就顺便买了一点。 （这是我的典型买币方式，信赖的大v推荐，就建仓。白皮书？创始人？投资方？nonono，都不需要的！这，很“韭菜”。）

 这个操作是在钱包里进行的。后来我想，如果是在交易所买的，也许故事会不同，谁知道呢。 

过了两天，我信赖的另一个v在社群里提醒，yfii是国内山寨分叉，警惕风险。 虽然我没啥操作，但这个提醒显然已经进入了我的潜意识。 

又过了两天，有个大群里ceo发了一张图，里面总结了几个暴跌的defi币种，yfii赫然在列——曾经从800刀跌到现在的100多刀。 我也还是没什么操作，但这条消息也被我大脑记住了。 

又过了几天，当我翻看买币软件时发现，其他币大部分都涨了，yfii还在跌，我已经浮亏1成多了。 我很烦躁。 

恰巧那几天，cy也没在群里再说yfii了。

也就是说，我脑中的负面消息占上风。 

于是，我花了高额gas，在钱包里把yfii又换回eth。

 过了仅仅两三天，yfii突然发车，翻倍，200刀。

 我有点懵逼。有点损失厌恶。有点纠结。有点矛盾。

 to追还是not to追？这是个问题。 追的话又是一笔高昂gas费。（其实也就一百块钱左右，现在想来，gas费算啥啊） 

还是算了吧。不追。好马不吃回头草。 

很快（一小时还是几小时还是一天我记不得了），yfii再次翻倍，400刀。 

心好痛。 损失厌恶加重。 

不追！ 

第三天，1000刀。

 操，“损失厌恶”四个字已经不足以形容我的痛苦了。 

“损失憎恨”。 

关于yfii，我试图不看不听不说。 

然而，铺天盖地的yfii暴涨的消息，躲不过。——这像极了爱情：失恋，被甩，不想知道那个甩你的ta的消息，可是，偏偏，还是会知道。 

尤其是cy大v已经开始大张旗鼓的宣传yfii了。社区海报喊单：目标8848刀。 

我的心，很煎熬。 不断自责：如果我当初不割肉就好了…… 

又过两天，随手看交易所软件行情，“不小心”又点到yfii里了。 

我靠，已经1500刀了， 而且，就在我看的时候，明显还在拉盘（其实我对k线知之甚少，但那个不断突破新高的状态任谁都能看出来）。 

我把持不住自己了，但理智在说：不能追高，不能追高。 感情说：追一点儿吧。 

于是，我在1900刀左右追了进去，买了一点点（对，我很节约）。 

买了后我就没管，有一种夙愿完成的感觉。 身心突然好舒泰。 看什么都变得美好了。 

第二天打开手机行情，傻了。 又翻了三倍。 昨天夜里最高到过5900刀。 现在还是5000多刀。 不但把之前亏的回本了，还多赚了。 

我本来该高兴的。 但，我更痛苦了。 

fomo模式启动。 

我不停的问自己：为什么昨天不多买点儿？！ 再这么涨下去咋办？！ 

我又开始自责了：如果当初多买点儿就好了。 那就等回调的时候赶紧加码吧？ 好，就这么办。 

这时，其实已经有yfii的社区大v好心提醒：不要追高，再等等。 

但我还是选择了在4700刀和3900刀分别接了两次。 

回来的两天，价格一直在3000—3709刀震荡。 

我又开始着急了：怎么还不拉盘呢？ （此时的我已经陷入了无脑韭菜模式，其实这时我应该暂时隔离整个币圈环境的） 

于是，我又一次不耐烦了。 我把钱撤出来，先是换了yfi，后来又把yfi卖了还cvp。 只留了一点点。 

如果故事到这里时，我能彻底消停下来，也算是不错的结局。 

但是，我低估了自己的“搞砸力”。 

昨天晚上，因为上架币安（我后来才知道），yfii经过两天多的盘整后再次飙车。 我本来应该坐在旁边开心看戏就好了。毕竟，我还是有一点点底仓啊（虽然很寒碜）。 

但是作精如我，又来了一个神操作—— 我竟然在目睹拉盘的过程中对自己说“不如来个超超短线吧”。 

于是，我竟然徒手接飞刀——高位买了。 

那时是晚上七点多。 

在我买后，盘面开始下跌。 （也可能我买的时候就变盘了，这 谁知道呢） 。我一边洗碗一边盯盘。 半个小时内，看价格跌了又小涨又跌又涨，但始终涨不回我买的价位。 这时，娃在旁边催我，快点一起学英语。 算了算了，不盯了，割肉。 

我把所有的yfii都卖了。 

最后一算，亏了。 

大脑有点空白。 

心里还在想。 耗费了那么多心力，最后亏了。 哎… 

八点多，我把碗刷完后，顺手看了眼其他的微信群。 看到有人说“一会儿不看拉那么猛”。 虽然那人的截图并未显示币种， 但我一看就知道那是yfii。 

又开始拉了？ 再杀进去！ 

此时的我已经杀红了眼。 用btc在0.53的点位换了一点。 我计算了一下，如果我7900刀挂单卖出，应该就能不赚不亏，回本。 

于是我这么做了。 但是—— （如果没有这个但是就好了） 

我还是忍不住盯盘了。 

只在给娃洗刷的20分钟里，没看盘。 结果发现，最高涨到过7400刀。 我自己洗澡的时候，看币价涨涨跌跌，大脑更乱了。 

但没再上过7200刀。 怎么办？要不改挂7000刀吧？ 

这时已经晚上十点半了。 娃催我睡觉睡觉。 我很烦躁：你自己先睡，别管我！ 最后娃在不开心的情绪中睡着了。 

其他微信群里有人说“明天又会崩吧？” 我又忍不住了。 

最后在6899刀的位置几乎出尽了。 只留了最后一点点yfii。 

这么点儿，不可能指望它再有啥了。就是个纪念吧。毕竟，耗了我那么多时间、精力、情绪。 结算下来，还是亏了。

这最后的一点yfii像是个讽刺，又像是个提醒：别再做韭菜了

20200830

本金的体量决定心态。
别人拿1w买个币随便玩玩，我拿1w就紧张的睡不着觉，这还咋尝试新鲜事物嘛？
所以目前还是用小零钱积累经验的阶段。
yfii得到的教训：
1）买一个标的之前一定要对它有最起码的了解；
2）无知割肉后，如果了解增多，那么就不要被损失厌恶的情绪控制，而要及时再上车。

20200823

最近几天一直因为自己错失一个疯狂涨的币而低气压，
虽然有股票投资经验的小伙伴提醒我不要因为一点儿得失而苛责自己，
但还是会忍不住懊悔，并试图做鸵鸟：取关、不看微信群消息，它再涨多少与我无关……
理智上知道，这样是不对的。
但心里实在接受不了。
大v们说，投资（机）是考验人性的，
这个人性指的是什么？贪，嗔，痴…
“炒币”的人就是容易陷在这些里。
所以，这其实也是一场很好的修行对不对。
所以，请慢慢平复心境，这本来就是个交学费、找厉炼的过程。
这也是个很好的认清自己的机会，
知道自己是中等资质，
就不要企图做那种低买高卖的操作，
安下心来，
不断学习积累知识、资料、成绩（以及，薪水），
尽可能用自己的脑子筛选出自己中意的标的，
然后，熊市布局，牛市收获，
就像耕种，顺应天时，春种秋收。
这是普通人的平稳、平静、乏味的投资练习之路。
不，其实能做到这些，已经不普通了。
加油

20200812

今天夜里又失眠了。
半夜醒了。
于是就开始想这两天的炒币经历。
想那些被自己踏空的币，本来都预设好的操作，没有执行下去，临时起意卖掉了。
当然，我本金很少，所以即使卖早了也损失不了多少钱。
而且，富贵在天。
我其实不用那么焦虑的。
不知道为啥，就是一直心浮气躁的感觉。
觉得自己数学太差，又不喜欢独立思考，不适合炒币。
安心定投比特币，吃beta收益，其实不也挺香的吗？
哎…

我今天夜里决定把KEY全部解锁，换成比特币。
同时，决定安心翻译，发文。

title: Vitalik在新的采访中谈DAO、以太坊和NFT
body:
关于比特币，V神说：“在某些方面，批评者的数量远不如支持者的力量重要。”

在最近与The Stakeborg Talks的播客采访中，以太坊联合创始人Vitalik Buterin坦率地谈到了一系列问题，包括他早期对数学和解决问题的兴趣，去中心化自治组织（DAO）的潜力，以及他对比特币社区和非同质化代币（NFT）领域的看法。

Buterin是一位谦虚的企业家，对自己的职业充满热情，在回答有关他对职业头衔的偏好的问题时，他称自己为技术哲学家，也许正是这样，他才创造了这个词。

引用雅典历史学家修昔底德(Thucydides)那句学者和战士的名言，Buterin对科技行业不断进步的信条与哲学中为思想领袖开辟的抽象空间之间不断变化的二分法进行了分析。

当被问及我们是否会看到以太坊不仅在价格价值上超过比特币，而且在作为储值资产方面超过比特币时，他简单地回答说“有可能”，然后扩展了他的观点：

> “我认为以太坊和比特币的最大区别在于，比特币是一个平台，其生态系统的价值来自BTC的价值，而在以太坊，ETH的价值来自其生态系统的价值。”

8月中旬以太坊备受期待的伦敦硬分叉升级正在增强该网络的交易支付系统，主要是交易费用和矿商收入方面。援引这一点，Buterin从上述对话中继续说道：

> “尤其是在引入EIP 1559后，当你销毁了费用，从更直接的经济意义上说，这就变成了事实。”

今年9月，Buterin因其在以太坊网络增长到超过4000亿美元市值的过程中所发挥的不可或缺的作用，登上了《时代周刊》的2021年100位最具影响力人物榜单。DeFi和NFT领域的领导者也获得了其他认可。

谈到去中心化自治组织的兴起，特别是二次方投票和融资等模式的发展，Buterin概述了Gitcoin DAO和Optimism追溯性公共产品实验，将其作为有发展景观的项目的例子。

当被问及DAO是否会成为加密货币生态系统中继去中心化金融和非同质化代币成功之后出现的下一个领域时，Buterin表示：

> “我认为随着时间的推移，DAO肯定会变得更加重要……就DAO领域中还缺少什么东西而言，我认为不会缺少任何大的东西，而更多的是许多小的东西。什么时候会有DAO首次决定打造战略中心，或者什么时候会有两个DAO决定合并？这是一种做出重大决定的能力，而不仅仅是在同一条道路上不断增长，我认为这是我们很快就会看到的。”

最后，在评论NFT领域的迅速崛起时，Buterin分享了一些关于被该资产吸引的新用户的见解：

> “我认为从文化角度来看，NFT很有趣，因为它们将人们带进以太坊，而他们的心态与DeFi和普通加密人士完全不同。”

title: Embarking on a Sonic Odyssey
body:
About a week or so ago, I was driving to the store, listening to the same few hundred song playlist on Spotify that I always listen to, bored out of my mind.  I’ve been bored by this solitary playlist for quite some time, but usually the feeling is fleeting.  I’m your typical, busy, middle aged dad, and in keeping with the cliché, it’s been a long time since music has been a particularly vital part of my life.

This time, for whatever reason, the boredom stuck with me.  The notion that music was a missing piece of my day to day experience resonated and moved me to do something about it.

Immediately, I realized that defining “something” was going to be a challenge.  When I was younger and music was critical to me, I never really discovered much on my own.  Instead, I picked up albums and artists from whatever hit the mainstream, or from what my more in touch friends would surface for me.  Then, once I found something I liked, I stuck with it ad nauseum.

So, I decided that “something” had to be a better idea than just dumping whatever albums I remember liking as a kid onto a new playlist.  That’s basically how I got the boring playlist in the first place.  Instead, I came up with a plan to grow, really engage with music and discover new things to connect with.

That plan is to set off on a musical journey through all of modern pop history, listening to anything and everything that might appeal to me, starting in 1962 and working my way year by year chronologically from then up to today and documenting what I find in this blog.  I expect to listen to a few dozen albums per year, and, assuming I stick with it, expect this endeavor to take the better part of a decade.

Although I’ll be taking a trip through music history, this project isn’t intended to be a historical documentation.  Rather, I’m taking this path because it seems like the most efficient way to find artists and their work.  Also, this blog isn’t intended as a critique, though I’m sure I’ll criticize quite a bit along the way.

Instead, this project is an entirely self-indulgent exercise, where I will cherry pick as I see fit, celebrate what I connect with and dump on the rest.  I’ll share what I think about as I navigate my way through time.

As befitting any odyssey, I expect the journey to be long, winding and uncertain, but that the destination is a worthy one.  I hope you enjoy the trip with me.

title: 20211022新闻摘抄
body:
20211022新闻摘抄

吴说获悉，经学反馈，DeBank数据显示，被为SBF的以太坊地址（0x84d34f4f83a8756cd3fb6887cff8f17bf5a7b83）通过去中心化社区衍生品平台选择Opyn，获得权日行日为2021年10月22日16日， 71,000 美元的比特币看涨期权和行权为 4,600 美元的以太坊看涨期权价格。

据 CoinDesk 报道，沃尔玛允许客户在其美国的特定家商店购买比特币。 一位 CoinDesk 编辑 10 月 12 日在使用州沃尔玛购买了少量 BTC，验证了服务有效。

title: Composable Membership and its Role in Generating Social Capital — Mirror
body:
Having a token brings a community together loosely with a financial stake, but composable membership holds a community together long term with social capital. That's a lot of buzzwords, so let’s explore this in three parts:

1.  How access, permissions, and status are the primary components of membership (and the role of tokens)
2.  Membership in Web2 versus Web3 platforms, and why composability matters here
3.  Designing a membership system to generate social capital

### **Access, Permissions, and Status**

Our [data and actions give us identity and relationships](https://ath.mirror.xyz/mDu_nGsWpjvF-KaPLADwxeAMfze3UJOtTAQi2CwPwWc), but having a social graph does not give you community. Put in a Web3 context, a group of people holding or trading the same token does not mean you are a community - at best, it gives you clusters. \*\*An actual community has fairly clear boundaries for growth (in more than a financial sense). You've probably seen some variation on the chart below\...

![https://github.com/orbit-love/orbit-model](https://ath.mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2F47N5kFjDdcNfmaliuCEPt.png\&w=3840\&q=90)![https://github.com/orbit-love/orbit-model](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

https\://github.com/orbit-love/orbit-model

... where you can identify your core contributors, and try to reward or incentivize them accordingly. Pet3rpan has put this concentric community chart nicely in a Web3 context, showcasing the funnel of activities a participant might engage in during their lifecycle in a community:

![https://medium.com/1kxnetwork/how-to-grow-decentralized-communities-1bf1044924f8 ](https://ath.mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FBsnO6\_CiiWfe9AELOdvJo.png\&w=3840\&q=90)![https://medium.com/1kxnetwork/how-to-grow-decentralized-communities-1bf1044924f8 ](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

https\://medium.com/1kxnetwork/how-to-grow-decentralized-communities-1bf1044924f8

But just because someone has participated in any of the above events, doesn't mean they feel like they're part of the community. Even giving them tokens for their participation doesn't really move the needle.

Tokens are open primitives that membership should be built upon, and just issuing more POAPs or tokens based on events and then moving on is like distributing the raw materials for a house and expecting the people to build up a town. Without a blueprint, people will just stash the materials and leave (or sell them to someone else). In crypto, we’re supply rich, but guidance poor.

Some communities at least take the first step to have some sort of access dependent on your token activities, usually a Discord server or channel. But access is only the first step to membership. Permissions are too closely tied to access right now, and status is left as too abstract a concept.

So let's improve on the current model. ***Access is discovery, permissions are responsibility, status is weight.*** This membership funnel is shaped different from the activity funnel above, as the customizable design area gets larger the deeper you go:

![](https://ath.mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FWUKtdEmRWd6lSriRuBSLs.png\&w=2048\&q=90)![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

These are basic examples, but they help lay the groundwork for how each layer could be tied to different types (and combinations) of tokens. Let's look at some token design examples for each level:

*   **Access:** For the most part, *ERC20's are best for access because requirements are fluid and the tokens are more liquid.* Today I might require 50 tokens to join, but in the future, I may drop it to 25 or increase it to 75 based on community needs (going wide versus deep). NFTs are cultural assets, so if you use that as the gate then it'll be tough to say you need two or more to have access now. Even if you implement project derivatives, liquidity becomes fragmented and confusing. This is project-dependent though, and Creator Cabins did a [great overview of some of the tradeoffs](https://creators.mirror.xyz/V7Ucba89-3qV9yFxj7Spj7YxjKAhc6TOd8nUcCp9n6k).
*   **Permissions:** *I personally believe permissions should be tightly coupled to a stake.* To be given the responsibility for some set of actions, there should be risk involved. Unlike access, permissions should evolve and can be revoked. If I'm making proposals, allowing staking will show my commitment and also give others the opportunity of *joining my stake*. This line of design can help a community better balance abuse of power and opportunities for discovery (of great new contributors).
*   **Status:** *This layer has the largest area because it is tied to attributes and metadata.* Status in a community has the highest amount of variance, as it will likely be event-dependent. Taking the treasury "weighted voting power" example, if you give status based on what is being voted on that highlights specific community members while also ensuring that it isn't always the participant with the most tokens has the most sway. NFTs are a great place to play with these attributes, especially through derivative and forge-based projects. *To clarify, this is not the same as reputation since reputation needs to be less fluid as to not confuse people. We'll get more into that later.*

Different combinations of these layers could be bundled into "roles" for easier management and assignment. I'd love to dive right into a membership system, but first we need to clear out the current mental heuristics around how Web2 "membership" works.

### Composable **Membership and the Role of Platforms (Web2 vs Web3)**

*In Web2, membership forms around services. In Web3, services from around membership.* Put simply, being a YouTube subscriber does not affect your privileges when engaging in a Twitch chat or a subreddit. This kind of membership interoperability is certainly possible in Web2, and I think Patreon was the closest to getting a hierarchical membership structure in place. We could have seen a world that looks like this:

![](https://ath.mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FvyHiSL8oyuqovbdFvnPpM.png\&w=1920\&q=90)![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

But obvious arguments would ensue over who owns the master API, and economic flow incentives also act as a blocker since the platform at the top of the hierarchy likely has the highest money-in/money-out flow and take-rate. So in the end we have like 7 or more different memberships to manage! No one actually wants that besides the platforms themselves.

In Web3, no one is fighting to be at the top of the membership hierarchy because the primitives (tokens) aren't owned by any one platform. Smart contracts are our APIs and we can code revenue splits right into them. If that isn't enough, we can devise governance and attribution systems over the treasury to ensure the services and tooling built around membership continuously benefits communities that rely on them. In the end, the above Web2 platforms will naturally fall lower on the hierarchy. **They will be forced to fit around the composable membership systems that we all enable and create. In other words, the community is the platform:**

![](https://ath.mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FtC63snvRPrTVJO8ayeVhz.png\&w=2048\&q=90)![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

There's an argument to be made that in the end, apps will just be a bunch of composable components where each piece is owned by a different platform. But in the interim, it'll be Web3 communities plugging into the currently better interfaces of Web2. When planning a membership system, we'll need to think about membership as bundles of access, permission, and status across these Web2 services. If I'm a multisig member, what roles will I need across all these services and how can that be managed in a single token/membership model? To figure this out, we'd need to experiment. And to experiment, we need social capital.

We've defined the components of membership and situated them within the Web2 and Web3 context. Now, let's have fun designing a system that could actually go into implementation. ***We'll define social capital as building an allowance for trust, experimentation, and flexibility within a community.*** This means having a membership system that improves ownership of decisions and prevents a social fork. For now, my guess is there are three main steps to execute membership and generate this new capital:

1.  **Define Roles:** Roles are bundles of the different layers of membership and are tied to specific participant personas. There are likely hundreds of combinations (especially if you layer token types on top), but some immediate roles that come to mind are:

    *   `Low Access (ERC20) + Low Permissions (ERC20 Stake) = new member`
    *   `High Permissions (ERC20 Stake) + High Status (NFT) = long time contributor`
    *   `High Access (NFT) + High Status (NFT) = subject matter expert`
    *   `High Access (ERC20) + High Permissions (ERC20 Stake) + High Status (NFT) = founding member`

    Doing this well opens up a pathway for growth and also clarity for all members. This starts to give us history too, as I can clearly see how a community has matured by its role definitions and distribution (much more so than if I just look at the token price).

2.  **Specify Incentivizes:** Pet3rpan mentioned in the article linked earlier that *trust and engagement are key to participation.* Financial incentives are a great starting point - if you airdropped me $1000 of your community's tokens, I'd definitely come to take a look and see what I can help with. But if these drops/bounties are filtered by role or membership history, we can be much more flexible with asks and rewards and I'd likely feel more fulfilled. This is the difference between me tackling a data bounty as a nobody versus as a Dune Wizard.

    This could also look like a hackathon where teams are built based on role/membership history, such that newer members are matched with older members. Or imagine if hackathon bounties rewarded community roles instead of just $$$, I think we'd end up seeing an even larger diversity of projects and teams in hackathons than we do today.

    Also, I cannot stress enough the importance of history here. `Membership + Identity + Relationships` will probably be the best proxy for a reputation score, which opens up the path to more creatively weighted incentives.

3.  **Assign Roles:** This step is more technically difficult than the others, given the challenge of plugging membership systems into existing platforms. I think this is similar to the integration problems that any wallet aggregator already faces, for example, Zapper's [protocol requests](https://features.zapper.fi/). Integrating into existing Web2 platforms shouldn't be difficult, but as more Web3 platforms are built the composability will be difficult to manage.

    But as long as we have an identity solution (connecting addresses to user metadata across platforms) and a membership solution (managing roles and tokens intuitively), I think we'll be able to tackle the platform integration problem elegantly. Besides, building the first two will take the ecosystem the next six months anyway.

Hopefully, this system helps show how much we can bring a community together while experimenting by using membership built off of tokens. I know for some people this is all still too fluffy, so I plan on doing data-driven case studies to better inform this kind of membership system in the future (and to try to be more quantitative about social capital). Some communities I'm interested in studying under this lens are Yearn, Blitmaps, and Superfluid - but if you have other case studies that come to mind, please do let me know.

## Concluding Thoughts

Composable membership shapes more than just communities, it will shape ecosystems and platforms as well. In crypto, we're all building platforms that give communities the tooling for implementation, visibility, collaboration, and much more. Ecosystems are forming around metadata already, and this will force a reorganization of Web2 platforms to provide a much more open surface to be built upon.

Mirror is one platform trying to improve the tooling for communities to implement a rewarding membership system:

![](https://ath.mirror.xyz/\_next/image?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.mirror-media.xyz%2Fpublication-images%2FJl7vf0FRlSNXu9PQZSo9T.png\&w=3840\&q=90)![](data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7)

Seed Club is a good example of the model above, where they [deploy ERC20 tokens for specific communities and causes](https://club.mirror.xyz/dnN3Dwe-iD6jBpzkase4YLHTxYtnuFnmUbSoOfPEkjI), and once members are more defined they move on to [specialized token distribution methods such as the token race](https://club.mirror.xyz/token-race/bafkreidnqdtyls7q62w6mvfuaiwzn52ivlvephw4wul7g5ph2lqbjzymom) for engaging the community and [adding new cohorts](https://club.mirror.xyz/Q5QwN3Uol03pOK8MhAVsfwc0ektDlrkrl6sVSoC2UwA). I think there is a lot more we all can do to standardize the membership implementation process laid out in this article, using Mirror and ecosystem tooling.

But none of what I've written about can sustainably happen unless communities take their thinking around membership more seriously (and that goes for me too). If any of this interests you, please reach out so that we can build out this future together. My [twitter DMs](https://twitter.com/andrewhong5297) are always open! 🙂

title: Artizen DAO
body:
[Artizen](https://www.artizen.fund/) is the largest platform for artist grants, and has pioneered a new model for community funded and curated grants. Our mission is to transform the way culture and public goods are funded, beginning with the arts. We are moving to web3 and invite you to join us as we build [Artizen DAO](https://artizen.link/pitch-deck).

Artizen helps communities come together and support the things they care about. We make it easy to create grants, raise money, curate awards, and reward donors with NFTs — a positive-feedback cycle that powers sustained support for your field, community, or cause.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wh78apEs5zDx5xZeMcWIm.jpg?height=1185&width=1920&size=medium)

## The Problem

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Baiou8j2Qv7gJFLh5Ka9C.png?height=838&width=2374&)

Grants are the lifeblood of the arts, but a new model for grants is deeply needed. The current system is centered around institutions, not communities, and as a result is bureaucratic, inefficient, and does not align incentives between donors, grantmakers, artists and fans:

* **Donors**: few rewards, no voice in curation, weak ties to artists, little stake in their success.
* **Grantmakers**: complex administration, overhead, challenges attracting and keeping donors.
* **Artists**: insufficient funding sources, onerous application processes, weak ties to donors. Few grants go directly to artists, most go to nonprofit gatekeepers who can afford full-time grant writers.
* **Fans**: not involved in the grant system at all, no incentive to become donors to a grant.

## The Solution

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/fJonlq5vZGNGax7qPdwWp.png?height=802&width=2380)

Artizen has developed a new model for grants that weaves all of these interests together.  By combining crowdfunding, community curation, and NFT rewards, we can unlock new money, untapped network effects, and robust support.

* By giving donors a voice in where their money goes, we give fans a reason to become donors;
* By eliminating bureaucracy, we give more money directly to artists, and simplify processes for both artists and grantmakers;
* And by rewarding donors with NFTs, we give everyone a stake in the project’s success, attracting more donors and creating stronger ties between supporters and artists.

## Artizen Grants Unite People

![The Dance by Matisse](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/S590-O_XWeO8WoW5-oULX.jpeg?height=997&width=1500)

Since launching our MVP in 2021, Artizen has awarded nearly $500K to artists across more than 100 grants, grown to 12K+ members, and partnered with major companies and cultural institutions including Microsoft, HP, Unity Technologies, and the Cannes and Tribeca Film Festivals. These partners are excited to underwrite community grants because we give them a way to directly support causes they care about, while removing the complexities of running a grant themselves.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_8fyRkr5vVNpe3BixCRYi.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

If you’re HP, or Academy Award Winner Viola Davis, and you want to encourage more Black visionaries to explore new technology, you can either create and run your own complicated incubator, mentorship or prize program – or you can simply back an Artizen grant.

## Artizen Curation Engine

Group decision-making is a challenge.  How do you give a voice to donors without making it just another popularity contest?  How can you give unknown artists an extra leg up?  How can a grantmaker guarantee high standards for winning artists, and keep a grant aligned with its original mission?  How do you create a positive, wagmi culture and avoid a dynamic of ‘winners’ vs. ‘losers’?   How do you balance the power of small donors against big donors?

We have been iterating on these difficult questions over 100 grant cycles.  The result is our Curation Engine, a selection system that balances and harmonizes these interests.  Grantmakers choose juries who select finalists, who can guarantee high standards and continuity of mission.  [Quadratic voting](https://vitalik.ca/general/2019/12/07/quadratic.html) balances small and large donor power while still incentivizing donation.  And everybody wins: splitting prizes proportionally to upvotes avoids the disappointment and bad blood of winner-take-all contests.

Here’s how a grant works in practice:

* Artists submit project proposals.
* Jury, selected by the grantmaker, chooses 3-10 finalists. 
* Community donates to buy upvotes. 
* Community votes for their favorite of the Finalists. 
* Project with the most votes is the winner, but all Finalists receive the donations behind the votes they got. 
* Winner creates an Artifact (more about this later).

![Artizen Curation Engine](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ZMRZDCSXjwYcQdEaX8zPa.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

## Community Curation Drives Growth

We’ve discovered something remarkable: community curation drives growth.  By giving donors a voice in selecting winners, artists have a reason to invite fans, and fans have a reason to become donors. The most successful Artizen grants grow rapidly because of this dynamic, and we are modeling the web3 version of Artizen on their success.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/FBwktpfurvbhcvq1zfSVV.png?height=908&width=2360)

title: Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？
body:
> 探讨 CryptoPunks 价值背后的潜在驱动因素，以及短期和长期内可以预期的潜在趋势。

### 什么是 CryptoPunks？

![Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？](https://img.chainnews.com/material/images/8743533166955e859a6dc1068c0c28ae_t0MTiGE.png-article)

CryptoPunks 是 10,000 个独特的可收藏角色的集合，被广泛认为是当今 CryptoArt 运动的开端。2017 年 6 月 23 日，Larva Labs 发布 CryptoPunks，当时任何人都可以免费获得 CryptoPunk。之后过程不再赘叙，发展到今天，根据 Nansen 的数据，Punks 目前的价格在 100.5 ETH （38.1 万美元）和 4,200 ETH （758 万美元）之间，使其成为最大的 NFT 藏品集，总市值为 1,262,143 ETH （45 亿美元）。

![Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？](https://img.chainnews.com/material/images/91c1667fdd1b52af84a6e760947f34aa_cHC4WXI.png-article)

### CryptoPunks 价值背后的潜在驱动因素

很多观察人士都难以理解收藏家最近为购买 CryptoPunks 所支付的高昂价格，认为形成了投机泡沫。其他人则认为，CryptoPunks 的价值是由 NFT 炒作浪潮之外的因素驱动，而最近的趋势可能只是揭开序幕，将迎来一场彻底改变艺术收藏的浪潮。

在本文中，我们进一步探讨了 CryptoPunks 价值背后的潜在驱动因素，以及短期和长期内可以预期的潜在趋势。

### 估值的基本面驱动因素

#### 史上第一个 NFT 项目相关的价值叙事

CryptoPunks 估值背后的第一个基本驱动因素是其作为历史上第一个 NFT 项目的价值叙事。这种价值叙事赋予了 CryptoPunks 在 NFT 领域中独一无二的地位。

这听起来令人印象深刻，但作为第一个 NFT 项目具体意味着什么，为什么这很重要？这意味着它是第一个使用区块链技术来代表独特资产所有权的项目。这产生了三个开创性的影响：

首先，CryptoPunks 彻底颠覆了艺术和艺术市场。通过利用区块链的所有权证明技术，CryptoPunks 消除了参与艺术品交易的第三方。艺术家现在可以直接与观众互动，以买卖自己的作品。区块链技术在艺术上的应用，真正可以实现数字艺术和收藏品在数字世界中的稀缺性，因为这些物品原本的可复制性特征，使其无法保证稀有和高价值。

其次，CryptoPunks 设立的榜样作用在广义上推动了新的资产类别出现：NFT。虽然艺术是其中一个用例，但现实中还有其他不可替代的资产（jpeg、meme、证书、专利等）利用所有权证明技术，使自身变得稀缺和高价值。

第三，它们激发了 ERC-721 代币的创建，后者是一种支持不可替代资产的代币标准，甚至在后者的白皮书中也提到了这一点。

#### 稀缺性

CryptoPunks 不仅在 NFT 领域具有重要的文化意义，而且它们也很稀缺。鉴于设立了 1 万个 的上限，使人们要获得其中一个变得很困难，否则它们就不会有什么价值。

CryptoPunks 在收藏层面上具备稀缺性，但现实收藏中这种稀缺性更为明显，因为其中部分 Punks 被认为比其他更稀缺。

Punks 的价值高低取决于它的类型、属性数量、属性组合和主观性。共存在 5 种 Punk 类型（外星人、僵尸、猿、男、女），87 种不同的属性，每个 Punk 最多有 7 种属性。

一般来说，被认为价值更高的类型是外星人、僵尸和猿。事实上，外星人的平均价格是男性 Punk 平均价格的 16 倍。

在属性方面，业界通常认为，拥有 0、6 或 7 个属性的 Punk 更有价值。

最受追捧的特征往往是最古怪和最具 Punk 精神的特征。目前，平均价格最高的特征如下：

* 小圆帽（Beanie）
* 飞行员头盔
* 帽衫（Hoodie）
* 头饰（Tiara）
* 项圈（Choker）
* 高顶礼帽（Top Hat）
* 橙边（Orange Side）
* 3D 眼镜
* 电焊护目镜（Welding Goggles）
* 金链子

重要的是要注意，最有价值的特征并不总是稀缺的。如果我们考虑这些特征随着时间的价值变迁，会发现很有意思的是，特征的受欢迎程度会随着时间的变化而变化。

![Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？](https://img.chainnews.com/material/images/2443b69b612d52a987189743248cee71_NgrPctQ.png-article)

如上图所示，帽衫和飞行员头盔等一些原本并不特别受欢迎的特征重新受到了重视。因此，实时掌握 CryptoPunks 社区（Discord、Twitter 等）中与特征相关的讨论，并充分利用最近的销售历史作为参考，这是非常重要的。

#### OG 社区的社交货币

如上所述，CryptoPunks 有独特的价值叙事和有限的供应量。这种稀缺性满足了接下来的这种需求：CryptoPunks 成了老炮儿（OG）社区和 NFT 领域中的一种社交货币。

购买 CryptoPunk 时，您不仅购买了图像，而且购买了 NFT 领域中最酷、最热门的 OG 俱乐部会员资格。这个俱乐部的会员资格有着非常强大的作用。它传达了这样一个信息，即您是先行者，您认识到该项目的历史意义，并且您在 NFT 领域是个名人。它还可以让您进入了重量级的社交圈子、可以进行独家对话、并可以免费申领其他 NFT 收藏品（例如在 Meebit 发布时）。

OG 不断增长的需求，以及市场中新参与者的入场，将进一步推动了 Punks 价格上行

随着时间推移，我们将看到不同市场参与者对 punks 的需求继续增加。OG 们会将先前收获的利润再投资于 CryptoPunks，或至少持有已经拥有的那些 punks。他们是经验丰富的收藏家。如下所示，CryptoPunks 的前 5 大持有者主要是原始收藏家，他们迄今仍然拥有 CryptoPunks 总数的 14%。

![Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？](https://img.chainnews.com/material/images/dc1a83bf57cb59adaf575cb5ea737af0_82s709P.png-article)

不过，随着时间变化，不同类型的 NFT 收藏家的交易演变也表明，「传奇 NFT 收藏家」的交易在总交易量中所占的比例越来越小。 （就 ERC721 代币交易而言，传奇收藏家意味着前 0.1% 的收藏家）

![Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？](https://img.chainnews.com/material/images/fa28e2d5ffa756f59564420e9218219c_Ssaqs1t.png-article)

实际上，虽然藏品最初主要集中在巨鲸手中，但随着时间的推移，CryptoPunks 持有者的数量一直在增加，这表明藏品分布变得更去中心化，也更趋于健康。现在大约有 3,000 名 CryptoPunks 持有者。

![Nansen：CryptoPunks 不可阻挡的涨势背后究竟有哪些推手？](https://img.chainnews.com/material/images/8fbc06a03500533880f2889265442e4d_PmFKrOk.png-article)

在这些新入局中，有高净值人士、投资人、名流和业界意见领袖。我们可以预期，他们受到短期 / 长期盈利前景，以及 CryptoPunks 社交货币属性的激励。

另外两个趋势也很明显。正如信用卡巨擘 Visa 上周购买 Punk 7610 所表明的那样，NFT 越来越受到机构投资者的关注。除此之外，随着 NFT 碎片化机制的出现，已经解锁出全新群体的市场参与者，碎片化机制可以让多人共同拥有一个 NFT。

#### NFT 整体市场的发展壮大，提升了 Cryptopunks 作为同类产品先驱者的地位

随着其他 NFT 收藏品的成功，例如 Autoglyphs、Bored Ape Yacht Club 和 ArtBlocks 的出现，而这一领域万象归宗，最终都会追溯到 CryptoPunks，CryptoPunks 将随着整体市场的发展而升值。

随着 NFT 领域的成熟，并与元宇宙、VR 和 AR 的融合，CryptoPunks 将成为更大市场中的一部分，并获得实际用途。

CryptoPunks 在不同媒体和行业中的传播也越来越多，例如 CryptoPunks 漫画、CryptoPunks 启发的衣服。Flamingo DAO 的一些成员甚至为他们的 Punk 创造了一个 3D 渲染图，将其存放于元宇宙中，而 Larva Labs 与好莱坞经纪机构 United Talent Agency 签署代理交易，意味着 tamen 很快就会出现在电影、电视和其他媒体中。这种异花授粉将使得 CryptoPunks 更受欢迎。不断增加的兴趣与稀缺性的碰撞，会推动 CryptoPunks 升值。

#### CryptoPunks 必然变成价值存储工具

由于只会存在一个 OG NFT 项目，CryptoPunks 将保持独特性，并且将成为 NFT 领域内的一种社交货币。随着 NFT 领域的成熟和新的市场参与者寻求获取 CryptoPunks，对这一系列藏品的需求将会增长。当这种增加的需求遭遇 CryptoPunks 只有 10000 个的上限时，CryptoPunks 会升值。随着时间变化，Punks 将成为一种价值储存手段，而且在 NFT 市场进入熊市时无疑会是最具价值韧性的。

### 结语

总而言之，CryptoPunks 价值的非凡增长可以通过基本驱动因素来解释，例如，它们作为历史上第一个 NFT 项目的价值叙事、其稀缺性和社交货币地位。上述元素将继续将 CryptoPunks 的价值推向更高的高度。虽然我们可以预期随着加密领域的行情起伏，CryptoPunks 的价格在短期内会有所波动，但从长远来看，CryptoPunks 的价值只会朝着一个方向发展。 CryptoPunks 仍将是最成熟的蓝筹 NFT 系列之一。

这仅仅是个开始。NFT 领域将继续存在，CryptoPunks 将永远被视为 NFT 的起源，并随着时间推移而获得更多价值。尽管这一系列的价值已经出现了惊人的增长，但预计到 2025 年时，Punks 的价值很可能会更高。

title: Artizen DAO
body:
[Artizen](https://www.artizen.fund/) is the largest platform for artist grants, and has pioneered a new model for community funded and curated grants. Our mission is to transform the way culture and public goods are funded, beginning with the arts. We are moving to web3 and invite you to join us as we build [Artizen DAO](https://artizen.link/pitch-deck).

Artizen helps communities come together and support the things they care about. We make it easy to create grants, raise money, curate awards, and reward donors with NFTs — a positive-feedback cycle that powers sustained support for your field, community, or cause.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wh78apEs5zDx5xZeMcWIm.jpg?height=1185&width=1920&&size=medium)

## The Problem

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Baiou8j2Qv7gJFLh5Ka9C.png?height=838&width=2374&)

Grants are the lifeblood of the arts, but a new model for grants is deeply needed. The current system is centered around institutions, not communities, and as a result is bureaucratic, inefficient, and does not align incentives between donors, grantmakers, artists and fans:

* **Donors**: few rewards, no voice in curation, weak ties to artists, little stake in their success.
* **Grantmakers**: complex administration, overhead, challenges attracting and keeping donors.
* **Artists**: insufficient funding sources, onerous application processes, weak ties to donors. Few grants go directly to artists, most go to nonprofit gatekeepers who can afford full-time grant writers.
* **Fans**: not involved in the grant system at all, no incentive to become donors to a grant.

## The Solution

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/fJonlq5vZGNGax7qPdwWp.png?height=802&width=2380)

Artizen has developed a new model for grants that weaves all of these interests together.  By combining crowdfunding, community curation, and NFT rewards, we can unlock new money, untapped network effects, and robust support.

* By giving donors a voice in where their money goes, we give fans a reason to become donors;
* By eliminating bureaucracy, we give more money directly to artists, and simplify processes for both artists and grantmakers;
* And by rewarding donors with NFTs, we give everyone a stake in the project’s success, attracting more donors and creating stronger ties between supporters and artists.

## Artizen Grants Unite People

![The Dance by Matisse](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/S590-O_XWeO8WoW5-oULX.jpeg?height=997&width=1500)

Since launching our MVP in 2021, Artizen has awarded nearly $500K to artists across more than 100 grants, grown to 12K+ members, and partnered with major companies and cultural institutions including Microsoft, HP, Unity Technologies, and the Cannes and Tribeca Film Festivals. These partners are excited to underwrite community grants because we give them a way to directly support causes they care about, while removing the complexities of running a grant themselves.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_8fyRkr5vVNpe3BixCRYi.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

If you’re HP, or Academy Award Winner Viola Davis, and you want to encourage more Black visionaries to explore new technology, you can either create and run your own complicated incubator, mentorship or prize program – or you can simply back an Artizen grant.

## Artizen Curation Engine

Group decision-making is a challenge.  How do you give a voice to donors without making it just another popularity contest?  How can you give unknown artists an extra leg up?  How can a grantmaker guarantee high standards for winning artists, and keep a grant aligned with its original mission?  How do you create a positive, wagmi culture and avoid a dynamic of ‘winners’ vs. ‘losers’?   How do you balance the power of small donors against big donors?

We have been iterating on these difficult questions over 100 grant cycles.  The result is our Curation Engine, a selection system that balances and harmonizes these interests.  Grantmakers choose juries who select finalists, who can guarantee high standards and continuity of mission.  [Quadratic voting](https://vitalik.ca/general/2019/12/07/quadratic.html) balances small and large donor power while still incentivizing donation.  And everybody wins: splitting prizes proportionally to upvotes avoids the disappointment and bad blood of winner-take-all contests.

Here’s how a grant works in practice:

* Artists submit project proposals.
* Jury, selected by the grantmaker, chooses 3-10 finalists.
* Community donates to buy upvotes.
* Community votes for their favorite of the Finalists.
* Project with the most votes is the winner, but all Finalists receive the donations behind the votes they got.
* Winner creates an Artifact (more about this later).

![Artizen Curation Engine](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ZMRZDCSXjwYcQdEaX8zPa.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

## Community Curation Drives Growth

We’ve discovered something remarkable: community curation drives growth.  By giving donors a voice in selecting winners, artists have a reason to invite fans, and fans have a reason to become donors. The most successful Artizen grants grow rapidly because of this dynamic, and we are modeling the web3 version of Artizen on their success.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/FBwktpfurvbhcvq1zfSVV.png?height=908&width=2360)

## NFT Rewards

We are building a new version of our platform on web3 for two reasons.  The first is to use NFT rewards to ‘close the loop,’ connecting the value of the art to the donors who support it.

For each grant cycle, donors will receive an NFT representing their support (a portion of an Artifact, described below).  Designed with the winning artist, it will combine the ideas of a POAP with NFT art – both a badge of support and a tangible asset that can appreciate in step with the growth of the artist’s career.  In addition, royalties from any trading of these tokens goes back into the Matching Fund to ‘pay forward’ into future grants.

NFTs will also connect the success of individual grants to the health of the whole grant ecosystem through the ARTIZEN ARTIFACTS.

![Vincent van Gogh's Ear](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/s4yb1XaI_f4cwNWANhrPr.gif?height=338&width=600)

## Artifacts Power the Artizen DAO

The second reason we are moving to web3 is because we want Artizen to be owned by its community.

Artizen Artifacts are NFTs that represent collective ownership of the platform, which will transition to a DAO structure.  Artifact holders will be investors, arts leaders, grantmakers and grantwinners, and anyone else invested in building a brighter future for art, science, and culture.

Royalties from Artifact sales go back into the Matching Fund, which will provide ongoing support for all grants.  Each grant cycle mints 3 new Artifacts, designed by the winning artist – one for the DAO, one for the artist, and one fractionalized as rewards to their donors.

As the company transitions to distributed governance, the community can experiment with new structures and policies.

The collection begins with 1,111 objects from the history of art around the world, designed by Nak Yong Choi with sound by Elliot Cole.  These 3D objects will be interoperable with Jadu, Sandbox, and elsewhere in the metaverse.

And finally, this collection (and community) will grow as new grantwinning work is also memorialized in Artifacts.

title: 一段旅程
body:
我想起老和尚和冯岚，他们让我明白，我不仅是一个难以提供温暖的人，更是一个难以接受温暖的人。面对善意不敢接受，反而企盼与自身内心深处的恶同等的恶意，这种固执的公平牢牢地将我攫住。几乎所有善意都在真假之间徘徊。而对我来说，真善比伪善可怕得多。因为无论伪装多么高明，伪善之人在施予的同时都想好了价码，这交易纵使并非情愿，总还能勉力完成。但面对真善，对于缺乏爱的能力的我，真是一次残疾者的长跑，爱就应当以爱来偿还，但我却无论如何使不上劲去爱。究竟如何是好？负债累累的我在偿还完毕之前永远是一个多吃多占的贼。我多希望我的债主们能干脆地将给予我的爱原封不动地收回，并狠狠地赠我一个白眼。这样我才能确认，他们只是恨我，并非对自己给予爱的行为产生怀疑。而恨对我来说是种解脱——与我心中的恶一一对照，这本就是我应得的。然而贼的身份与爱的残疾一样，如胎记般印在我身上。仿佛这世界上所有乐善好施者的背后都有一面镜子，在人们将传言中最美好的“爱”以近乎强奸的方式不由分说施加于我的过程中，我看到的只是镜子中自己因惊慌而向下的唇角和疲倦至极的眼神。

不知为什么，只有面对沈秋的善意时，我才感到轻松和清白。

我乞求世界上所有的人都离我而去，只留下沈秋一个。我真的这么乞求。

现在沈秋在哪儿呢？

我在卧铺车厢窗边坐下。由成都出发的火车，行驶五个小时以内，不管去往东南西北，理应都是青山绿水。而我在极目远眺中却恍若置身一个月前开往柳园的列车：灰黑的秃山形同驻扎着满腹恶窦的矮人的营地，帐篷间隔着飞砂与黄土，小兽携着犹疑偶尔穿梭而过。一眼望不到头的云翳不轻不重地拢盖像魔鬼的手搁在猫头上。而幻想沈秋的我在被暖气包裹的列车中箭似的从这个大部落穿插而过。

沈秋在哪儿呢？

“快餐供应有需要的吗？”女列车员慵懒的叫卖声像打桩机一样把我的幻想凿开一个又一个洞。恍惚中，无处不在的方便面味儿、窗外本色的峰峦叠翠挤破头从洞中涌入。“叭”的一声，电影谢幕开灯一般，火车上的种种情境又实实在在撞到我跟前。我往大衣口袋里摸烟，一包干瘪的软壳利群里还剩一根头上受了潮的烟。我走到厕所门口，把烟头掐了大口地抽。如是，“沈秋在哪儿”的回响才慢慢升腾，我的脖子、背脊、臀部，一切她牢牢紧箍过的地方又呈现她双臂的触感。这感觉原来并不随着她身处何方而转移，我发现这一点，深吸一口气，烟不慎脱手掉在潮湿的地上“咝”的一声灭了。

下一次见她是什么样？这个疑问随同我的眼睑一同合上了，一丝荫翳掠过眼角，随之而来的是掩盖着跃跃欲试的金黄色光芒的黑暗。“呼…呼…”车门的缝隙中传来风声，使黑暗滚动起来，添上了时间的维度，我仿佛成为在黝黑车轮中翻滚的石子。

下午过半，阳光从逐渐稀薄的云翳中呼啸而下。车厢中又有了光影，我头顶的行李架上原本如陈旧血渍样的铁锈忽然显出鲤鱼鳞片一般的光彩。我将手伸入光线中，良久，手心中冒出细密的汗珠。我攥起手掌，脉搏从湿热的掌中传来，仿佛抟着一枚心脏。光，原本最直白的虚无，由于带来这样的暖意，便在人类身边阒然居住下来。想到这里，我便又企盼蕴藏无数寓意的黑夜降临。

火车在黄昏时骤然停了下来，车厢喇叭中适时地传来播音：由于铁路管制，火车将在此地稍作停留，出发时间未知，请乘客们耐心等待。

“哎哟喂，他妈的什么叫稍作停留？”不远处中铺的男人探出半枚光头向下铺说到。

“都是放屁。”那人轻蔑一笑，随即起身从行李架上拽下包。不一会儿，一条青筋隆起的手臂从包里带出两副扑克甩到桌上。

“来来来，下来打牌！”他拍拍中铺的屁股，麻利地从铺位底下拖出两个破旧的黑行李箱叠起来。

“还有没有人掼蛋哦？”他摩挲着手掌朝铺满落日余晖的走廊里大喊。

一位谢顶的老头诺诺地从座位上站起来点点头：“我淮安来的。”

“噢！老乡老乡，我们泰州的！”中铺男子向前迎了迎，拍拍老头的肩将他安置在下铺坐定。

“小伙子你会不会？”他向坐在斜对过的我微微颌首，“还差一个来玩玩嘛。”

“唔，那来嘛。”我放下手中的保温杯与老头并肩而坐。最后进来的中铺男子在我对面坐定，朝我尴尬一笑：“小伙子要不你跟他换个位子？”他轻推下铺男子示意着。

“哎呀换什么，就这么来嘛。”下铺男子一边不耐烦道，一边极为迅速地洗牌切牌，“都一样，来，小伙子先摸牌。”

三两局牌之后我将对家的习性摸清，我们之间的配合逐渐圆熟起来。不多久，我们便升级到k，领先于对方的7。中铺男子每打到紧要时便侧身抓一掬瓜子，一边嗑着瓜子，一边翘首企盼我放出令他满意的牌型。一天中最后的阳光射在他的光头上，鱼卵般的细汗若隐若现，他头皮繁密的纹理愈发模糊，如同死鱼的肚皮。

这时车厢的灯打开了。恍然间，车窗外翠绿的山脉如同青鸟合上了翅膀，只留下缄默的躯体，山上所有的枝叶都因黑暗垂首，缩成一个坚固的轮廓。远处的紫霞如寺庙的香火般燃烧天地的妙相，裹挟着通体赤红的群雁袅袅而去。我感到意义从黑暗中喷薄下来，浇湿了发光的车身，这光失去了暖意的掩护，终于暴露出虚无的胴体，在时空中无处躲藏。

恍惚中，我开始胡乱地出牌，并暗中观察对家的神色。戏谑的快感让我浑身燥热。几局莫名其妙的输牌之后，他的眼睛呈现出强压下的红肿，狠狠地怒视着我。沐浴在他的凶光中，我愈发觉得自己的躯体真实起来——我终于摆脱了惯性，逃离周蔚用善意铺就的处世之道。我深知的藏匿于体内的恶此时正毫无保留地通过手中的牌倾泻而出，我将用这无瑕的恶在我身周虚无的光中搭建出一间暗房，饕餮其中饱含的意义。

终于，在对方打到A后，中铺男子“哗”地站起身，紧紧揪住我的衣领：“你他妈打的什么牌？”

沐浴在雪白灯光中的我仍在为这粹生于虚无中的纯洁之恶叹服不已，我兀自笑起来。“砰”的一声，一枚重拳呼向我的鼻梁。眼镜断成两截在光中飞动着散落赤红的地毯之上。接着，恶毫无保留地从我的肢体中流泻出来…

从火车警务室回到车厢时，车已经移动了一阵，进入一片雨带。中铺和下铺男子早已与我言好，邀我去餐车喝几杯。我盼着听火车通过武汉长江大桥时空旷的回响，便婉言谢绝了。

回到卧铺躺下，对铺男人像受到威胁的狗儿发出荷荷的鼾声。近视使我失去焦点，黑暗囫囵地涌入我的眼睛。我凝神细听雨点播撒的声音，好似一颗颗瞳仁般的种子落入我的心田。这种子会生长成什么？想象着，乘务员哼着轻快的曲子穿过走廊，她轻盈的剪影从窗纱上倏而滑落。窗外，老人一般佝偻的路灯用白光扫射着车厢，为卧铺中熟睡的人一遍遍涂上厚重的乳釉，他们促狭的体态最终凝固在逼仄的空间中，与火车融为一体，驶向实像世界中的光明与目的去了。“空隆，空隆…”轮机重复的传动声使得这景象更为壮观。方才落在我心田中的种子汹涌地冒出芽来——我猛地发现我的下身坚硬了起来。

……自慰后我很快进入了梦乡，我梦见成百上千只小羊瞪着玻璃球一样的眼睛径直向我走来，从我身上碾压过去，留下只剩意念的我，远远地走了……

再醒来时，武汉长江大桥早已经错过。此后的路程里阳光大好，车厢里干爽宜人。对铺孩子的父母请我帮他们批改作业，我欣然答应。

“你赞赏文中小猪见义勇为的行为吗？请写出三条赞赏的理由。”

“不赞赏。”

诸如此类的问题孩子都这样回答，我被逗得直笑，“这孩子真是不简单啊！”

孩子父亲听见我的话拿过作业本看看，也开朗地笑了起来，一口烟牙像烤得干瘪的玉米仁，“真是伤脑筋喂。”说着他搂过正在拼装小汽车的孩子使劲摸他的头，孩子倔强地挣脱开，又专心地干活了。

“要是能像你们一样考上大学就有出息喽。”孩子母亲说着，手里打着毛线，一条毛线裤已经打了一条裤腿儿，狐狸尾巴一样垂着煞是可爱。

“上了大学也不一定有出息，孩子以后修车也一样能有出息的。”

“就是！”父亲猛地一拍大腿，“你看，还是大学生说话在理！”

“噫！你们两个说话倒是滑稽！我就是嫁了你这个修车的才在这里打毛衣！”母亲的眉毛一竖，手里动得更快了。

“现在不是也挺好？我可是亏待过你？”

“我是有苦都往心里掖着哟！”母亲说着反倒笑了，脸颊上一层健康的红嫣慢慢浮了起来。

我一路批改着作业，时而抽一两颗烟，似乎不多久就到了上海。

title: 公链为王
body:
![chain list](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/1aDo0o3qDp-R70OXnoxuC.png?height=992&width=1415)

2021年，如果说哪个板块表现最好，我会说是公链，如上图，几乎都是今年的明星项目（除最后一个）

看着这些项目的表现，真的有一种早年投资美股5大科技巨头的感觉，这是21世纪前十年的Google，Facebook，Apple吗？

随着传统资本加速进入加密货币领域，除了最受益的比特币外，接下来就肯定是这些龙头项目了

下面逐个来聊聊：

* **Ethereum**

  以太链，毫无疑问绝对的龙头，最靠谱的智能链，传统资本最认可，前景一片光明，很有机会发展成为巨无霸

  目前聚集了大批的defi，NFT头部项目，也是所有重量级创新选手首选的部署平台

  目前市值是排名第二的BNB的6倍，我个人认为差距应该往着缩小的方向发展
* **BNB**

  cex & dex双重赋能，800亿这个市值是偏低的，币安是绝对的龙头

  而之所以最近BNB的表现并不容易，很大的原因就来源于币安受到了打压，而最近币安的表现，真是顽强，越挫越勇，关注度，流量，交易量都是节节攀升，宇宙第一地位进一步巩固

  而说到BSC生态，那也是第二繁荣的，主要表现在defi和gamefi上面，特别是gamefi，最有希望。明显也可以看出币安在大力扶持BSC上的gamefi，虽然现在的游戏还是有点粗糙，但是全面开花也是很有盼头的

  我的主要资金也是放在BSC上，用着习惯，方便，也看好它的前景
* **solana**

  这是最让我遗憾的项目，几乎是首批链上玩家，当时的SOL也就2U附近，现在都已经200U了。这是一条标榜高性能的新链，不支持EVM，早期可能还不成熟的时候，我玩了，体验非常差，就刻板地认为这是一条韭菜链，于是一直没怎么关注

  当初2U买的3个用作gas fee的SOL也在100多清掉了，然后一路踏空

  sbf是这一期最闪亮的星，大力资助了拜登的选举后，感觉FTX最近在政策方面一路绿灯，而币安却处处受阻，大有FTX迎头赶上的势头，后面很可能会两巨并驾齐驱

  当前，SOL与BNB市值相当，尽管发展不错，但我还是相对更看好BNB
* **Polkadot**

  从营销之王，到迟迟拿不出作品，被质疑EOS之流，确实不让人省心

  主打跨链，但是当前EVM的跨链更为繁荣

  加上市值这么高，没有多少炒作的空间，相对不看好
* **Terra**

  韩国王者，基于Cosmos技术，生态开始繁荣，日后打通IBC之后，也是很有看点的

  市值也相对较高
* **Avalanche**

  这个不太了解哦，只知道支持EVM，没发现有什么特色，搞不懂为啥那么贵
* **Polygon**

  开始以为是ETH的layer 2，结果被证伪，神奇的是，很多ETH头部项目都会部署一个polygon版本，主要是解决贵族链手续费贵的问题

  这个我也不是很懂，跳过
* **Cosmos**

  主打跨链的二王之一，当初名气口碑都比不上polkadot，更是被binance和OK弃用（最初binance发展的是binance chain，就是基于Cosmos的，后面发现不能打，投身ethereum fork出了基于EVM的BSC，OKT同理）

  但是随着慢慢发展，走出了明星项目Terra，还有二线的kava，最近又开始整合资源，发展前景不错，如果能成，Cosmos是要上一个台阶的，所以性价比相对来说很不错
* **Famton**

  defi界名人AC大力扶持，支持EVM，最近生态发展也不错，较为引人注目的项目是前期上线的fork AAVE的geist，锁了100亿资金，说明还是不缺钱的，还算能打

  另外市值相对便宜，性价比不错
* **NEAR**

  新链，不怎么了解
* **EOS**

  拉胯王子

纯粹个人分享，记录，非投资建议

title: Artizen DAO
body:
[Artizen](https://www.artizen.fund/) is the largest platform for artist grants, and has pioneered a new model for community funded and curated grants. Our mission is to transform the way culture and public goods are funded, beginning with the arts. We are moving to web3 and invite you to join us as we build [Artizen DAO](https://artizen.link/pitch-deck).

Artizen helps communities come together and support the things they care about. We make it easy to create grants, raise money, curate awards, and reward donors with NFTs — a positive-feedback cycle that powers sustained support for your field, community, or cause.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/wh78apEs5zDx5xZeMcWIm.jpg?height=1185&width=1920&&&&size=medium)

## The Problem

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Baiou8j2Qv7gJFLh5Ka9C.png?height=838&width=2374&)

Grants are the lifeblood of the arts, but a new model for grants is deeply needed. The current system is centered around institutions, not communities, and as a result is bureaucratic, inefficient, and does not align incentives between donors, grantmakers, artists and fans:

* **Donors**: few rewards, no voice in curation, weak ties to artists, little stake in their success.
* **Grantmakers**: complex administration, overhead, challenges attracting and keeping donors.
* **Artists**: insufficient funding sources, onerous application processes, weak ties to donors. Few grants go directly to artists, most go to nonprofit gatekeepers who can afford full-time grant writers.
* **Fans**: not involved in the grant system at all, no incentive to become donors to a grant.

## The Solution

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/fJonlq5vZGNGax7qPdwWp.png?height=802&width=2380)

Artizen has developed a new model for grants that weaves all of these interests together.  By combining crowdfunding, community curation, and NFT rewards, we can unlock new money, untapped network effects, and robust support.

* By giving donors a voice in where their money goes, we give fans a reason to become donors;
* By eliminating bureaucracy, we give more money directly to artists, and simplify processes for both artists and grantmakers;
* And by rewarding donors with NFTs, we give everyone a stake in the project’s success, attracting more donors and creating stronger ties between supporters and artists.

## Artizen Grants Unite People

![The Dance by Matisse](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/S590-O_XWeO8WoW5-oULX.jpeg?height=997&width=1500)

Since launching our MVP in 2021, Artizen has awarded nearly $500K to artists across more than 100 grants, grown to 12K+ members, and partnered with major companies and cultural institutions including Microsoft, HP, Unity Technologies, and the Cannes and Tribeca Film Festivals. These partners are excited to underwrite community grants because we give them a way to directly support causes they care about, while removing the complexities of running a grant themselves.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/_8fyRkr5vVNpe3BixCRYi.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

If you’re HP, or Academy Award Winner Viola Davis, and you want to encourage more Black visionaries to explore new technology, you can either create and run your own complicated incubator, mentorship or prize program – or you can simply back an Artizen grant.

## Artizen Curation Engine

Group decision-making is a challenge.  How do you give a voice to donors without making it just another popularity contest?  How can you give unknown artists an extra leg up?  How can a grantmaker guarantee high standards for winning artists, and keep a grant aligned with its original mission?  How do you create a positive, wagmi culture and avoid a dynamic of ‘winners’ vs. ‘losers’?   How do you balance the power of small donors against big donors?

We have been iterating on these difficult questions over 100 grant cycles.  The result is our Curation Engine, a selection system that balances and harmonizes these interests.  Grantmakers choose juries who select finalists, who can guarantee high standards and continuity of mission.  [Quadratic voting](https://vitalik.ca/general/2019/12/07/quadratic.html) balances small and large donor power while still incentivizing donation.  And everybody wins: splitting prizes proportionally to upvotes avoids the disappointment and bad blood of winner-take-all contests.

Here’s how a grant works in practice:

* Artists submit project proposals.
* Jury, selected by the grantmaker, chooses 3-10 finalists.
* Community donates to buy upvotes.
* Community votes for their favorite of the Finalists.
* Project with the most votes is the winner, but all Finalists receive the donations behind the votes they got.
* Winner creates an Artifact (more about this later).

![Artizen Curation Engine](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/ZMRZDCSXjwYcQdEaX8zPa.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

## Community Curation Drives Growth

We’ve discovered something remarkable: community curation drives growth.  By giving donors a voice in selecting winners, artists have a reason to invite fans, and fans have a reason to become donors. The most successful Artizen grants grow rapidly because of this dynamic, and we are modeling the web3 version of Artizen on their success.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/FBwktpfurvbhcvq1zfSVV.png?height=908&width=2360)

## NFT Rewards

We are building a new version of our platform on web3 for two reasons.  The first is to use NFT rewards to ‘close the loop,’ connecting the value of the art to the donors who support it.

For each grant cycle, donors will receive an NFT representing their support (a portion of an Artifact, described below).  Designed with the winning artist, it will combine the ideas of a POAP with NFT art – both a badge of support and a tangible asset that can appreciate in step with the growth of the artist’s career.  In addition, royalties from any trading of these tokens goes back into the Matching Fund to ‘pay forward’ into future grants.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/H0CJWMuc8iMDHrGYku6rT.jpg?height=1260&width=2410)

NFTs will also connect the success of individual grants to the health of the whole grant ecosystem through the ARTIZEN ARTIFACTS.

![Vincent van Gogh's Ear](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/s4yb1XaI_f4cwNWANhrPr.gif?height=338&width=600)

## Artifacts Power the Artizen DAO

The second reason we are moving to web3 is because we want Artizen to be owned by its community.

Artizen Artifacts are NFTs that represent collective ownership of the platform, which will transition to a DAO structure.  Artifact holders will be investors, arts leaders, grantmakers and grantwinners, and anyone else invested in building a brighter future for art, science, and culture.

Royalties from Artifact sales go back into the Matching Fund, which will provide ongoing support for all grants.  Each grant cycle mints 3 new Artifacts, designed by the winning artist – one for the DAO, one for the artist, and one fractionalized as rewards to their donors.

As the company transitions to distributed governance, the community can experiment with new structures and policies.

The collection begins with 1,111 objects from the history of art around the world, designed by Nak Yong Choi with sound by Elliot Cole.  These 3D objects will be interoperable with Jadu, Sandbox, and elsewhere in the metaverse.

And finally, this collection (and community) will grow as new grantwinning work is also memorialized in Artifacts.

title: Fintech App Current Taps Coinbase’s Bison Trails to Support Polkadot DeFi Plans
body:
Fintech company Current is one step closer to bringing decentralized finance (DeFi) features to its 3 million users.

The firm said Thursday it is working with Bison Trails, the blockchain infrastructure company acquired by Coinbase in [January](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2021/01/19/coinbase-buys-blockchain-infrastructure-startup-bison-trails/), to sync up with Polkadot parachain networks Karura and Acala. The fintech first announced its crypto plans in [May](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2021/05/18/banking-app-current-picks-polkadot-for-its-defi-debut/).

Current says it’s looking to combine DeFi services with the best of its traditional offerings in a bid to meet the growing needs of crypto-curious retail investors. Along with travel app [Maps.me](http://maps.me/) [toying](https://www.coindesk.com/business/2021/02/24/alameda-leads-40m-round-in-defi-prime-brokerage-plans-mapsme-integration/) with DeFi features on Solana, Current represents an emerging crop of aspiring fintech-DeFi mashups.

“We’ve flirted with bringing crypto back into our project for a while now, but there were always obstacles in the way,” Current Chief Technology Officer Trevor Marshall told CoinDesk in an interview. “When DeFi really took off in 2019 we were able to get over a lot of the technical hurdles.”

The company first attempted to offer DeFi services with Ripple and later Ethereum, dating as far back as 2015, though neither came to fruition due to technical limitations, Marshall said.

“The launch of our cluster on Karura is the first step in the evolution of what we’ve been building over the past six years at Current,” he added in a statement.

Said Acala co-founder Bette Chen:

“These two organizations \[Current and Bison Trails\] share our vision of a hybrid finance (HyFi) future, and we are excited to continue building products and networks that improve financial outcomes for the Current, Acala and Karura communities.”

title: Lassoing a Stallion: How Gary Gensler Could Approach DeFi Enforcement
body:
Earlier this week, we considered the challenges of creating viable long-term regulations for decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols. These systems can ostensibly remove intermediaries from the trading of any asset represented on a blockchain, but those intermediaries have been the ones enforcing rules on behalf of regulators for the better part of a century. That means workable DeFi regulation will likely be much different in substance, and enforced differently, than current securities and finance rules.

That rethink may be years away from occurring, but U.S. regulators aren’t sitting idly in the meantime. With Securities and Exchange Commission chief Gary Gensler signaling that he’s paying attention, there’s significant expectation that enforcement actions could target DeFi well before any new regulations become official. Those enforcement actions will likely prioritize instances of clear lawbreaking, such as fraud or money laundering, taking place on DeFi systems.

This op-ed is part of “Policy Week,” a forum for discussing how regulators are reckoning with crypto (and vice versa). David Z. Morris is CoinDesk’s chief insights columnist.

They will be significant tests for the legal implications of decentralization. And they could get very, very ugly – particularly for individuals running “DeFi” systems that aren’t very decentralized at all.

Here, based on conversations with lawyers, former regulators and DeFi executives, are three key points about how things are likely to play out over coming months and years.

1. Enforcement will come before new rules.

The first ugly truth about DeFi regulation is that it will inevitably come too late. Systems like UniSwap and Celsius were built in ways that challenge the fundamental premises of conventional financial regulation, but regulators will not be quick to shift their models to conform with the reality on the ground. Meanwhile, DeFi systems continue to grow, guaranteeing they’ll face increasing scrutiny.

Jai Massari, a partner focused on trading and markets at the law firm Davis, Polk and Wardwell, predicts a three-step process of reconciling those conflicting truths. Call it the Stages of Regulatory Grieving.

“I think it starts off with enforcement,” she says, “because enforcement is easier than regulation.” Those enforcements could be similar to recent actions that have led to large fines for crypto exchanges like Kraken or services like Tether. But they could also go further to include criminal charges against individuals, on which more below.

Then we’ll begin to “see an effort \[by regulators\] to push these DeFi activities into existing regulatory categories,” Massari says. “But I don’t think that’s going to go well. I think it could be quite messy.”

In other words, she doesn’t expect serious consideration of a new regulatory framework that actually fits how DeFi works until after regulators spend time trying to hammer square pegs into round holes. In the U.S. context that could include jurisdictional fights between the SEC and other financial regulators.

Plenty of crypto operators will rightly view putting enforcement ahead of regulation as shutting the barn door after the horse is loose. To some extent, it’s a consequence of the shifting priorities of a new administration. Trump administration regulators, for better or for worse, made only incremental progress on laying out rules for crypto, much less DeFi, as crypto and DeFi grew from marginal to meaningful between 2016 and 2020.

There are signs regulators see things as running out of control. “It appears \[Gary Gensler is\] aligned with people like \[Massachusetts Sen.\] Elizabeth Warren that it’s the wild west, that it’s under-regulated,” says Katherine Kirkpatrick, co-chair of the Financial Services working group at the law firm King & Spalding.

Gary Gensler and Co., in other words, see themselves as trying to lasso a galloping stallion. That may lead to particularly strong enforcement tactics.

“They’re operating from the perspective of trying to solve something that’s the most egregious thing going on using traditional law enforcement tools,” Duane Pozza, a former Federal Trade Commission staffer who is now a partner at Wiley Law. “Because it means there will be fewer limits.”

1. Investigators will “Pierce the Veil” of decentralization.

In principle, DeFi protocols run without owners, leaders or managers. Much like Bitcoin, the protocols are in principle just software run by a collection of node operators or validators who neutrally facilitate transactions while collecting liquidity yield and fees.

Governance decisions, including changes to the protocol itself, could also in principle be managed by users. But there are still few examples of this in practice today; instead, the reality of “DeFi” in the present is often that it’s a fig leaf for a very clear group of core leaders who are actually in charge. The clearest evidence of this is instances where accounts, tokens or entire “decentralized” systems have been frozen or shut down.

“One of the design decisions in an autonomous system is whether there’s a kill switch,” says Stephen Palley, a lawyer focused largely on crypto regulation at Anderson Kill. “The problem with a kill switch is, what’s the liability or exposure of the person who controls it? To be truly autonomous, you can’t have a kill switch. The absence of that is a way to say you’re not responsible.”

It’s a grim irony of DeFi’s coming collision with legal reality: DeFi administrators who have been taking direct action to control problematic activity may have given law enforcement clear evidence that they’re actually the ones in charge, making themselves targets.

Particularly in cases where there is no legal entity affiliated with a DeFi platform, experts say this could lead to regulators and investigators “piercing the veil” in their DeFi enforcement actions. “Piercing the veil” is a legal term of art normally applied to prosecutions of corporate wrongdoing that target individual officers of the company, not just the legal corporation itself.

At least two recent crypto prosecutions have shown the willingness of the SEC and others to pierce the veil of crypto organizations, even those that have conventional corporate structures. One was the SEC’s charging of individuals at Ripple, including CEO Brad Garlinghouse, with an unregistered securities offering. The other was the filing of money laundering-related criminal charges against officers of BitMEX, including CEO Arthur Hayes.

Similar direct action against individuals with control over DeFi systems may not be far off. SEC chief Gensler has already made clear that he views most claims of decentralization in DeFi with skepticism. In addition to use of kill switches, law enforcement may look for evidence of control and responsibility in public representations of a protocols team, or and control of multisig wallet keys.

1. Clarity will not come soon.

It will be extremely tricky to craft regulation that controls risks like fraud and money laundering through DeFi while preserving technological advantages like open access, self-custody and democratic governance. That could be worth the trade-off in the long term if new rules are truly crafted carefully.

“We’re at a moment where a bit of enlightened thinking about regulation, a little creativity, a little open-mindedness would result in a much better outcome,” says Jai Massari. “I think the best approach is to take a step back and think about the policy objectives we’re looking for.”

That process could easily take years. In the meantime, enforcement actions will likely ramp up, perhaps leaving DeFi creators and administrators in the difficult position of defending themselves for breaking rules that simply can’t be fairly applied to the new technology.

Even then, there’s no guarantee that competent and well-considered regulation will be the end result. As we saw over the summer with the poorly crafted reporting requirements in the U.S. infrastructure bill, there is still a large technical deficit in technical knowledge among legislators and regulators, and it can have serious consequences.

“The technological shortfall is pretty significant,” says Duane Pozza. “The lawmakers have a million other things going on. We’re far away from getting to the point of understanding DeFi. I do think the infrastructure bill was a wakeup call – at least some influential people on \[Capitol\] Hill had to learn, had to think through this new technology.”

That leaves an uncomfortable status quo, at least for those in the world’s largest financial market. For a period that could stretch for years, there will be no changes to U.S. financial regulations to accommodate the way DeFi really works. But at the same time, law enforcement and regulators will likely be making life very uncomfortable for anyone who could be seen as having authority or control over DeFi systems.

Unless something changes very soon, that will almost certainly push innovation in DeFi out of the United States, much as huge, centralized crypto exchanges including Binance and BitMEX found it more comfortable to center their operations elsewhere. It’s a message that at least some would-be creators are getting directly from their legal advisers.

“I might not agree with the application of certain laws to what my clients do, but I’m not the \[Commodity Futures Trading Commission\], I’m not the SEC,” says Palley. “I’m just a simple country lawyer and I have to call balls and strikes.

“So I spend a lot of time just telling people to stay out of the United States. I hate it, but it’s good advice.”

title: Biden expects gasoline prices to fall in 2022
body:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - President Joe Biden said on Thursday he expects gasoline prices to fall in 2022 and that any further price reduction depends on factors such as the actions of Saudi Arabia.

Earlier today, Reuters reported that U.S. antitrust regulators have extended the approval process https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/exclusive-us-slows-down-oil-gas-mergers-sources-2021-10-21 for at least five oil and gas mergers and acquisitions in the last three months, as the Biden administration scrutinizes deals to tackle soaring energy prices.

title: 译文｜机构入局加密领域
body:
原文翻译于2019-07-02

在区块链/加密行业中，2019年，可以说是“机构进场”的一年。

 

尽管，在加密领域中，机构是常被引用的催化剂，但它入场的进展缓慢。毕竟，这些是风险可能巨大的大型组织，因此他们希望小心谨慎地接受新的创新和机会。

 

然而，我们终于看到了来自传统科技和金融机构的真正动力 - Square，微软，富达和Facebook都在宣布进军这个领域。

 

不可否认，在上一次加密牛市之后的两年内，机构和企业已经进场。但，他们为什么选择现在呢？这对未来意味着什么？

 

### “我们用区块链”

 

从高层面上看，机构正寻求进军区块链的原因有这几个：研究和开发，增长机会，以及在很多情况下，FOMO（害怕错过）。

 

对于许多机构来说，他们正在进行研究和开发，以了解技术并获得对整个景观的看法。随着越来越多的公司决定在该领域进行试验，以及寻求获得早期增长和收入机会并抵御破坏性风险，机构们的竞争压力急剧增加。

 

此外，大型企业内部的创新是保留人才的重要组成部分，因为越来越多的人才离开华尔街，而去担任加密创业公司的技术角色。

 

我们也正目睹金融服务领域的大规模人口变化。金融机构目前正在为老龄化的客户群提供服务，并且在很多情况下都在努力捕捉更年轻、更精通技术的客户的思想和钱包份额。为了了解这些人口统计数据，加密资产是一种值得关注的趋势。

 

FOMO，是主要原因  - 没有人愿意“错过这条船”，这可能是一个巨大的增长机会，或者，忽视它可能会给他们的商业模式带来风险。这也引发了对该领域的深思熟虑的分析，以及一些所谓的“创新剧场” - 为了“用区块链”而用。

 

越来越多的机构接纳这个领域，这将为该行业带来积极因素。但是，当我们从试验阶段和POC（proof-of-concepts）阶段转向严肃的实施、产品和服务时，细节就很重要。

 

而且，作为一个行业，重要的是**鼓励对该技术进行采用的最佳用例，而不是简单地建立新的内部数据库。**

 

### 这些机构是谁？

 

机构一词过于宽泛---实际上，我们看到许多类型的公司进入这个领域。为简单起见，下表主要对美国的机构和企业进行了分类。它不全面，只是更具代表性。

 

 

 
 

虽然我们有大量的玩家进入这个领域，但他们不能被平等对待。相反，这些组织要么作为“创新项目”而影响深远，要么保持孤立。

 

为了了解潜在的结果，我们考量了他们现有的客户群、他们面临的市场趋势和风险承受能力、以及，这些组织内部的人才、这些人才如何塑造对加密领域的内部视角。

 

### 资产配置

投资角色：基金，家族办公室，捐赠基金，养老金计划

投资形式：风险基金，对冲基金和直接投资

示例：斯坦福，麻省理工学院，普林斯顿大学

 

随着加密资产成为一种新的资产类别，资产分配者不得不围绕整个技术和领域进行思考。

 

Cambridge Associates最近发布了他们的报告“Venture into the Unknown”（《冒险进入未知世界》），他们评估了加密资产配置策略，并建议投资者考虑对数字资产进行配置。

 

他们的建议源于这样一种信念，即，区块链投资可以比作早期的互联网投资，充满了年轻的、有风险的技术，最终可能刺激下一轮资本流入。

 

从资产配置者的角度来看，对行业的投资开始在其投资组合策略中发挥重要的多元化作用。考虑因素包括：哪种类型的投资适合其战略（例如，风险投资与对冲），投资类型的经理（新兴专业人士或终身专员）以及资产类别的流动性状况（具有更高的代币流动性，但到目前为止在行业没有进行IPO）。

 

自2017年牛市以来，机构参与的专用加密风险投资和对冲基金已经筹集了超过10亿美元（Blockchain Capital 1.5亿美元，A16z 3亿美元，Paradigm 4亿美元，Dragonfly 1亿美元，等等）。资产配置是市场增长和任何新行业资本形成率的重要指标。

 

### 传统金融机构

投资角色：托管人，交易所，经纪人，资产管理人和银行

投资形式：贸易和执行服务，保管，场外交易OTC

示例：Fidelity，ICE（Bakkt），JPMorgan，DRW

 

传统的金融机构正在谨慎地观察这个领域，有些机构选择无视，有些则倾向于进入这个领域。

 

直到最近，许多加密资产对传统机构现有业务构成严重威胁和机遇。无论他们的地位如何，它几乎成为每个金融服务机构内的战略监视区。

 

从历史上看，金融服务对其他行业普遍存在的数字化反应迟缓。

 

然而，随着在线机器人顾问和数字银行的兴起，金融科技已经开始蚕食传统机构的产品和定价策略。这些机构都面临着类似的趋势：老龄化的投资者群体、所有产品和服务费用的压缩、千禧一代的品牌忠诚度降低、基础设施过时、以及客户对更多加密教育和访问的需求增加。

 

从战略计划来看，机构一直在寻找机会，希望通过大型增长型市场和利润率较高的产品，来实现收入来源的多元化。这需要他们在风险承受能力与快速做出决策并利用现有基础设施适应市场的能力之间去平衡。

 

正如Castle Island Ventures的合伙人Matt Walsh所说，最好的机构将切入“创新剧院”，并真正尝试了解他们如何利用这项技术。

 

一方面，像富达这类机构，他们深入了解整个生态系统（采矿，贸易执行，监管等），并采取措施提供监管和最终执行服务。

 

另一方面，摩根大通这类企业所发行的代币更为保守，他们通过创建POC的内部工具来进入该领域，而不是创收或面向客户的产品。

 

### 金融科技Fintech

投资角色：以技术为重点，金融服务提供商

投资形式：经纪服务，投资组合管理

示例：Robinhood，Square，SoFi

 

Fintech与加密技术保持良好的合作关系--- 两者都有共同的目标，即，利用技术来覆盖无法使用银行的人群，以及更便宜、更容易获得的产品。这与年轻、精通技术、财务状况较差的消费者的人口统计重叠。这个背景加上轻巧的操作以及更新的技术基础设施，使得金融科技公司非常有能力捕捉到加密利益。

 

最初，我们看到像Robinhood这样的经纪产品和像Square这样的POS系统首次进入这个领域 。事实上，Square的最新年度收益报告显示，他们在2019年从比特币中获得1.66亿美元的收入，净利润为169万美元。

 

这里的动机**不是颠覆，而是更关注如何利用技术和资产来刺激新的增长和满足客户需求**。

 

### 支付公司

投资角色：信用卡公司，支付处理器，汇款服务

投资形式：通过风险投资和合作伙伴进行战略投资

示例：VISA，PayPal

 

支付或成为“交易媒介”是加密算法的原始用例之一。

 

随着时间的推移，我们已经意识到，大多数发达国家的支付渠道实际上运转得非常好，并且可能由于某些原因而无法引入加密货币。

 

（加密支付）最常被诟病是传统的规模问题，例如，区块链无法处理Visa所处理的数百万笔交易的规模。

 

然而，更重要的是，从法币转换到加密货币，然后在跨境汇款的另一边再次转换为法币（称为“最后一英里问题”）的额外摩擦，在很大程度上超过了今天用加密处理支付所带来的任何价值。

 

当然，在一个场景下，加密支付开始变得更有意义，那就是，人们单独持有数字资产并能够更自由地与进行交易。

 

此时，支付公司需要考虑的一个主要问题是，持有和交易数字资产的宏观趋势如何影响其业务模式。换句话说，他们现有的客户将来如何使用数字资产以及这会对他们的市场产生什么影响。一些场景包括：消费者经常使用多个数字钱包、在法币和加密货币中进行商业活动、或选择自我保管其部分或全部数字资产。

 

到目前为止，支付公司对加密货币潜力的反应速度较慢。但是，如果随着这些宏观趋势的加速，在确定适当机会后，许多机构会大幅增加他们的参与度，这不足为奇。

 

### 社交媒体

投资角色：通讯App，社交网络

投资形式：钱包基础设施，令牌

示例：Facebook Libra，Telegram，Kakao

 

社交媒体和加密资产的重叠，是当今最值得关注的趋势之一。

 

有两种角度可以思考这一点。

 

首先，从加密视角到社交媒体平台。在加密方面，社交媒体采用数字资产有可能在全球范围内大规模开放分销渠道。这对于吸引新用户、构建基础设施以及传播接受度和意识具有重要意义。

 
 

Facebook的天秤座（Libra）并非被视为比特币的竞争者，而是被视为更多用户采用比特币的门户。

 

第二个角度，是对数字资产的采用将如何改变社交媒体商业模式。社交媒体平台正在从共享用户生成的信息转向提供用户生成的产品和服务。

 

Instagram已经与成千上万的影响者建立了社交媒体业务及其最新的应用内购买功能。

 

随着Libra对推出，Facebook正在大力发展金融服务，以补充其庞大的广告技术业务。

 

类似于直接发短信或“DM-ing”与千禧一代电子邮件竞争的方式，社交媒体数字钱包是否会与世界各地的经纪公司和银行竞争？

 

另一方面，社交媒体巨头代表了加密传教士试图反对的东西（即中心化垄断）：中心化权力、不平等地访问消费者数据和隐私控制。因此，社交媒体公司接受加密的方式将非常重要。

 

如果成功，它可以将模型从中心化式权力转移到开放平台，为用户提供更大的隐私保护。

 

### 软件企业

投资角色：SaaS，基础设施

投资形式：企业区块链，供应链使用案例，身份认证

示例：Microsoft，Salesforce，IBM，Amazon

 

软件企业历来陷入创新的陷阱。

 

从他们的角度来看，他们试图了解公链和私链如何对他们的商业模式有用。在许多情况下，这引发了对私链POC的应用，仅此而已。 

 
 

然而，用这一领域（以及人工智能和机器学习等其他技术）的技术作为保持竞争力和相关性的方式，其实存在很大压力。

 

微软则是一个好榜样。它宣布了基于比特币的分布式身份识别工具。

 

希望业界能够看到这样的计划，旨在与开源社区合作，并了解公共协议的App，而不是聚焦封闭的私有链。

 

### 我们要到哪里去？

有大量的机构正进入加密领域，每个机构都有自己的角度和价值主张。

 

该行业已经见证了超过10亿美元的资金配置给专用的加密基金，这将刺激该领域的下一波初创公司和资本形成。

 

随着越来越多的机构进入，我们将看到更多的流动性和线上大规模的分销渠道以及以公用事业为重点的产品和服务。

 

也许，最重要的是，这些组织内部的专业人员将被迫了解这个领域、对其优点进行辩论和学习。这将使区块链和加密货币从流行语和POC阶段，转变为真正被理解并被纳入战略产品路线图。

 

这个领域正在慢慢进入主流，而随着像Libra这样的项目不断推出，会有更多的机构参与进来。

 

感谢Spencer Bogart，Derek Hsue，Aleks Larsen提供的有用反馈。
